Topic.Title: Here's my preview for Amazon's Earnings tomorrow

Message.Msg: True, but across the board we're seeing a 10% drop in revenue from manufacturers and that is year over year. Amazon only had 9 billion in revenue a year ago. Most of their revenue gain since is from Kindle Fires which was the number one selling product for Amazon. It's a real travesty that they do not release sales figures for it. Roughly 800 million in Q4 and 500 million in Q1 Kindles sold. As far as market share we know Best Buy and Radio Shack, etc.. are suffering. However if you look at Radio Shack's earnings revenue actually increased by 1% year over year even though Consumer Electronics sales according to US Census has dropped year over year. http://www.census.gov/retail/marts/www/download/text/advt1.txt Electronics & appliance stores Year over Year - 2012 vs 2011 June - 8,151 vs 8,232 billion May - 8,213 vs 8,205 billion April - 8,156 vs 8,404 billion Net sales down 325 billion year over year Amazon is not included in those figures since they are under Non-Store Retailers which shows a 10% increase year over year. June 36,056 vs 32,172 billion May 35,886 vs 32,516 billion April 35,540 vs 31,983 billion That 10% increase for Q2 is the slowest increase since Q3 of 2010 and analysts are expecting a 30% increase for Amazon which they managed to hit in Q1 when year over year spending was up 17%. Q3 2009 -2% Q4 2009 3% Q1 2010 10% Q2 2010 9% Q3 2010 9% Q4 2010 11% Q1 2011 12% Q2 2011 14% Q3 2011 13% Q4 2011 14% Q1 2012 17% I don't know if this was a factor, but a lot was spent on travel in Q1 so more people were away in Q2. We also had major power outages and you can't really shop electronically when your computer is down.

Message.Msg: AWS revenue in Q1 was in the "Other" category which totaled 500 million. It was probably around 350 million total and not a big contributor.

Topic.Title: Here's my preview for Amazon's Earnings tomorrow

Message.Msg: Did some more estimates and I'm lowering my revenue projection to 12.35 Billion max. This is based on a Q2 10% year over year growth in E-Commerce which is lower than the 17% year over year growth in Q1. It also takes into account revenue from Kindle Fires which wasn't available last year. This doesn't take into account any weakness in Europe or any currency rate impact. This doesn't take into account any product mix shifts away from consumer electronics into other retail categories. The facts are. The weather was good in Q1 and people were out spending. This pulled future sales revenue from Q2 into Q1.

Message.Msg: Hey Paul, I've seen you on here for last week or so and read a few of your posts. Amazed, and glad, to see that you are on the short side this stock. As to "how fast" Amzn will fall and "how far", of course you are right. It should have a "big" fall tonight and then a "slow steady' drift lower from there over time, not just days, but weeks and months. Do I actually think Amzn will fall $100 over just a handful of days? No. Do I think it is "possible" ? Yes. Topic.Title: I dont know what to do...

Message.Msg: I'm short at $228 using October Put Spreads. Revenue will be below expectations and traditionally Amazon's stock price has been driven by revenue growth. Profitability has always been ignored. I think this quarter will mark a significant shift in focus from revenue growth to margins and investor reaction is a big unknown right now. Amazon has 1.5% margins. Target and Walmart are in the 20% to 28% range. Amazon can improve their margins quite a bit, but it will require significant investments in warehouses, logistics, etc.. I don't think Amazon has a choice in this matter. There is a global recession on the way so 30% year over year growth in revenue is going to be really difficult. They may be shifting and trying to improve margins. The question will be whether this company will still be viewed as a growth firm deserving of a 200 plus PE ratio once they start battening down the hatches. There is a lot of uncertainty right now and the smart move is to take profits and run..

Message.Msg: You're right. Improving margins will rely on. 1. Increasing 3rd party sales. This is not really something Amazon can control with the global macro picture deteriorating. 2. Improving Cost of Goods sold. This is where warehouses come in play especially in states like California. Freight charges to ship goods of the docks around San Fran and LA to existing warehouses in Phoenix and Las Vegas is expensive especially if you have to ship packages back into California. There is a lot of work Amazon needs to do if it is looking at a revenue growth slowdown.

Message.Msg: For the second-quarter, the company reported earnings fell 96% to $7 million, or 1 cent a share, from $191 million, or 41 cents a share a year ago. Shares are down 2% at $216 in late trading, but are narrowing the loss. The company projected third-quarter sales would be between $12.9-$14.3 billion, a gain of 19-31%, with an operating loss of between $350-$50 million, down from a profit of $79 million a year ago. http://blogs.wsj.com/marketbeat/2012/07/26/amazon-earnings-as-expected-slide-sharply/?mod=yahoo_hs

Topic.Title: It still is a revenue story

Message.Msg: Kenji: It is a trading profits story. Very smart HFT/algos make a lot of money around here. I wonder what the take was on options for this OE? The essential truth is that Apple, Google, and WalMart will all be aggressively gunning for Amazon. It started a multiple front war, not with weak mom and pop retailers, but with the biggest, best, most profitable and most well resourced (see aggregate cash on hand) companies in the world. With Amazon having to collect sales tax and with those folks competing head to head far more aggressively, cash flow from operations will fall further. Investors will truly get spooked when AMZN has to start cutting deep into its current cash position to fund this speculative dream. That, and the prospect of increased capital gains tax will tax this down in the back half. But, as I told everyone, expect the scam to last longer than you think possible... Good luck all...

Message.Title: Amazon com Announces Second Quarter Sales up 29% to $12.83 Billion
Message.Msg: Amazon com Announces Second Quarter Sales up 29% to $12.83 Billion SEATTLE--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Jul. 26, 2012-- Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) today announced financial results for its second quarter ended June 30, 2012. Operating cash flow was $3.22 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with $3.21 billion for the trailing twelve months ended June 30, 2011. Free cash flow decreased 40% to $1.10 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with $1.83 billion for the trailing twelve months ended June 30, 2011. Common shares outstanding plus shares underlying stock-based awards totaled 468 million on June 30, 2012, consistent with 468 million one year ago. Net sales increased 29% to $12.83 billion in the second quarter, compared with $9.91 billion in second quarter 2011. Excluding the $272 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates throughout the quarter, net sales would have grown 32% compared with second quarter 2011. Operating income was $107 million in the second quarter, compared with $201 million in second quarter 2011. The unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates throughout the quarter on operating income was $8 million. Net income decreased 96% to $7 million in the second quarter, or $0.01 per diluted share, compared with net income of $191 million, or $0.41 per diluted share, in second quarter 2011. The second quarter 2012 includes $65 million of estimated net loss related to the acquisition and integration of Kiva Systems, Inc. “Amazon Prime is now the best bargain in the history of shopping – that is not hyperbole,” said Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon.com. “We successfully launched Prime seven years ago with free unlimited two-day shipping on one million items. The price of annual membership was $79. Since then, Prime selection has grown to 15 million items. We've also added 18,000 movies and TV episodes available for unlimited streaming. And we’ve added the Kindle Owners’ Lending Library – borrow 170,000 books for free with no due dates – it even includes all seven Harry Potter books. What hasn’t changed since we launched Prime? The price. It’s still $79. We’re very grateful to our Prime members, and thank them whole-heartedly for the business and for the word-of-mouth that has made this program grow.” Highlights http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=97664&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1719126&highlight=

Message.Title: something no one understands
Message.Msg: Amazon will indeed keep buiding infrastructure--no doubt about it. They will never make decent margins because as soon as they increase prices the consumer goes elsewhere. This is a company that can have massive sales and NO PROFIT! Message.Title: The war between Amazon and Wal-Mart
Message.Msg: There is only one reason to invest in AMZN: one day Amazon will beat Wal-Mart! But is it possible? Currently, Amazon has only about 1/10 of Wal-Mart's sale, and has to sacrifice profit to make just 1/10 of Wal-Mart's sale. If Amazon wants to make 2/10 of Wal-Mart's sale, it has to burn money. How much cash Amazon could be able to burn? So it's very simple: AMZN is very unlikely to replace Wal-Mart. But even if Amazon replace Wal-Mart, Wal-Mart has only about $250 billion market cap, just 2.5 times of Amazon Market cap. In other words, the best ROI on Amazon will be just 1.5 times profit. Worth taking the risky? For me absolutely no. Insane to invest in AMZN.

Message.Msg: Zuckerberg sold 30.2 million shares at a price of $37.58 for gross proceeds of $1.13 billion --- acebook's Zuckerberg, Thiel sell shares Market Pulse May 22, 2012|Laura Mandaro ShareEmailPrint SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Facebook Inc. (US:fb) Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg has sold 30.2 million shares and director Peter Thiel has sold 16.8 million shares of the social-networking company, according to securities filings published late Tuesday. The sales confirm plans detailed in a prospectus before Friday's $16 billion IPO. Zuckerberg sold 30.2 million shares at a price of $37.58 for gross proceeds of $1.13 billion; Thiel sold 16.8 million shares for gross proceeds of $633 million. Facebook insiders had told prospective shareholders of their plans in an S-1 filing last week. Facebook (US:fb) shares were down 0.8% after hours at $30.74.

Topic.Title: AMZN is an Organized Crime Scene

Message.Msg: The HFT machines and their banking/hedge fund owners have figured out how to buy and cancel their trades in AMZN without actually settling trades. In essence, the cartel has limitless money to "buy" AMZN and push the stock to "sustainable" levels for very short term periods. About 10% of their trades never settle, meaning no cash changes hands at the end of the day. The AH trading is evidence of this scam. Shorts enter the pool after terrible AMZN numbers, and then, on light volume and without any real settlement, they push the market higher, forcing the shorts to cover. The only real money changing hands is new short money, transferred in part to the HFT machines. It is not real trading, but the authorities are clueless to understand the problem and even more clueless to stop it. How this scam ends now is anybody's guess. The market valuation is incapable of going any higher, given AMZN is now losing money, and likely will lose even more money, regardless of revenue growth, on a go forward basis. RIMM eventually broke the cartel in 2008, when market forces overwhelmed the scam. I do not know what the catalyst will be for AMZN.

Message.Title: Best Option Strategy (in my opinion)
Message.Msg: on these horrifically overvalued stocks (AMZN, CRM, etc.) is to buy well-in-the money puts a few months out (when the stock price pops) and then sell near-the-money puts against them. Basically put debit spreads. We know they will ultimately succumb to gravity, but we don't know when. If we're short the near-the-money puts when they finally do tank, we miss out on some of the downside. But if they stay bloated for a few more months or years (admittedly not likely...), we can make money most every month. Right now I'm long some October 300 puts. Sold some 215 and 225 puts against them. Captured all that nice juicy option premium (average $10 each) and still have the long puts. Best thing I can think of to do at this point . . .

Topic.Title: completely OUTRAGEOUS. Should be down at least 20%.

Message.Msg: That would be me. I've been looking over the earnings report to figure out what was the difference. It comes down to a single non operating income / expense item: Other income (expense), net $50 million for Q2 vs -$99 million for Q1. That $150 million in difference there is $0.20 in EPS. I expected a repeat this quarter which would of lowered EPS to -$0.19. I was wrong. I thought a drop in the EURO would make this figure worse. It had the opposite affect. I just pulled up a chart of the EURO vs USD. It actually rose for the first three months of the year and has since plummeted. http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/currency/EURUSD I'm assuming there are accounts payable (Amazon has like 9 months to pay suppliers?) in EUROs on the books and the drop in the EURO has created an accounting gain in USD to the tune of $50 million USD. The Q1 adjustment of $(99) million was probably exaggerated from large accounts payable from Q4 holiday sales. This should be a non factor in Q3 since accounts payable has shrunk from -$4 billion in Q1 to about $182 million in Q2. So what is funny is that Amazon reports that the revenue was impacted by FX changes and would of been higher, but they don't report on the flip side that the same FX change has created a non operating gain on account payable balances.

Topic.Title: Best Option Strategy (in my opinion)

Message.Msg: So you're doing a bearish diagonal. I like it, good strategy. But for me it's more capital than I would like to commit to the position at this time. So what I do is each time the IV is high I sell an oom call spread. Just this Monday I sold the Aug $240-$250 spread, collecting $250 per contract pair. (Spreading $230-240 would have worked, but I wanted some padding for security.) With earnings passed, the implied volatility is going to come way down. So I can probably cover tomorrow for about $1, or just wait til August and let them expire worthless. Both approaches are pretty similar, profiting from stable or downward movement. But yours probably costs what, $7000-$8000 cash per contact with $1000 income per month? That's fine, but I like smaller increments and would rather collect than spend so I'm happy to take in $250 x as many contracts as I like. Just different sides of the same coin. I do like your strategy and just wanted to offer an alternative approach that also works for someone with a smaller portfolio.

Topic.Title: Best Option Strategy (in my opinion)

Message.Msg: You're absolutely right Mitt, It most certainly isn't risk free. However, I've yet to find an options strategy that could be considered completely "risk free". Spreads, straddles, butterflies, condors, calendar spreads etc. are all useful strategies for mitigating risk... but (alas) none are completely safe. The strategy that you've outlined is excellent. However, if the stock price continues to go up the Put Option that you've purchased will lose value. The Put Option that you sold will certainly help mitigate some of the loss, but not completely. Ultimately, it's all about risk management.

Message.Title: Amazon is in a Trading Range 175-235 for options
Message.Msg: Seems to me Amazon is in a trading range which gravitates to the middle of that range each time earnings are released. Last quarter the right move prior to earnings was a bull call spread. Long the 190 or. 195 and short the 205 or 210, because the stock was at the low end of the range. this quarter it was in the middle of that range, so the right move was a butterfly call spread or it's equivalent betting on low volatility. Long the 200 double short the 220 and long the 240. I am not sure what will get amazon out of this range, but will continue using this strategy until it doesn't work. The net cost of the butterfly was $4.50 And the maximum gain is $20 less the cost at 20, and one dollar less for each point away. The win zone was 205-235. Hopefully it will close tomorrrow in that range. Looking for comments from option players.

Message.Title: What the analysts should have asked...
Message.Msg: 1) What is AMZN's share of retail purchases in states/regions that collect tax versus those that don't? One number (which I hope AMZN execs will have to disclose under oath before Congress in the next Main Street Fairness hearing...) could have greatly clarified the likely impact on AMZN's future revenues (and how much the artificial subsidy has helped it get where it is....) 2) Your ROIC is constantly declining. What is you target LT ROIC? What is your ROIC hurdle rate for new investments, particularly physical infrastructure, which seems to be increasing margins only by sinking excess capital to provide minimal incremental leverage? 3) How much more cash/infrastructure investment do you expect will be necessary to fully service the "closer to consumer" model nationally? 4) Was the shortfall in content growth the reason cash burn was so high? If AMZN's share of digital media/content sales were to drop close to the level of its device share, what would that do to your cash flows? How will you prevent Apple and Google from increasing "stickiness" with their device owners, especially in light of the new cloud services they offer? Those 4 would have been far more illumating than the softball crap they asked...

Topic.Title: What the analysts should have asked...

Message.Msg: "if price is the same everywhere and stored in clous to access on all devices, which apple and Google can afford to do), then Amazon will lose ground in a big way" But the price isn't the same and the other companies can't cope with this as it is playing the game on Amazon's terms. We found this out when Apple broke the law and colluded with the big publishers. That pretty much confirmed the fact that no company however large see itself as able to cope with Amazon within the law that is. And even by breaking the law they couldn't. Content may one day be available on all devices via the cloud but it will likely end up being Amazon's cloud since the masses who have already bought into the Kindle platform are unlikely to endure switching costs involved in abandoning the hundreds or thousands of titles that already make up their current Kindle e-book libraries. This is why Amazon invests a lot initially in locking consumers in early but shorts only see this in terms of what the impact was to the short-term ROIC metrics. This kind of action by Amazon has to be about the most aggressive thing any company in the history of American commerce has ever engaged in but the clueless shorts somehow think it is "defensive".

Topic.Title: What the analysts should have asked...

Message.Msg: Nemesis: You Are Clueless. The publishers were trying to keep the price high. Apple does not need it high and neither does Google. Apple makes its money from hardware (although it generates vastly more cash from Apps and media already than Amazon does on its ipentire business -- by about an order of magnitude...). Google makes money from Ads. Neither needs to charge a penny above the royalty fees on digital content. They shouldn't. They should sink Amazon quickly and harshly. Amazon is trying to sell their products as loss leaders and turnabout is fair play. Amazon is can/should/will get a beat down. Google and Apple will port the content to their respective clouds (Google already does it with music). Sure, legacy books will still be in Amazon's proprietary format, but books aren't like music. People don't typically read them many times. It is the FLOW that matters... This will all become clear by the end of 2013, but probably much sooner....

Topic.Title: Simple answer for amzn being up in AH

Message.Msg: "The spending on facilities will have to be done as revenue grows." All this happens in cycles however. You will first see a prolonged period of higher profit before any spending of this scale is seen again. And so on... "They have never made hardly any money.... " If this is a double negative then it is true. They made $billions during the period prior to the current expansion. "..and never will." He better hope so, folks, 'cause he shorted from $180 and is currently eating it. "When the business slows, and/or state sales taxes kick in they will have an over supply of these facilities and....." Internet sales are one of the fastest growing and longest runway business around so none of the former is likely to happen in your lifetime at least. Deals have already been struck in many places not to collect sales tax even once the legislation goes into effect. Shorts only see it as an overflow because they have no idea what the size of the market is and how much larger it will become.
